page.title: 11Rivers
page.content: The predominant feature of the Eastern section of the area under study, which lies between the village of {Rhuddlan}to the North and the Cathedral city of{Saint Asaph}to the south is the broad, flat valley of the {River Clwyd},and to the south, its tributary, the{River Elwy}.The land is given over mainly to agriculture, with grassland, cereal crops, and dairy farming prominent The rivers themselves provide salmon and trout{fishing}and are popular with local anglers. The area was frequently subjected to{flooding}during the 1960s and levees were built to reinforce the banks. Parallel to the course of the river is found a dual carriageway road, which links the communities of Rhuddlan and Saint Asaph. Between the road and the river is found the bed of
